articles.headline: Europe Retaliates Against Trump Tariffs
articles.snippet: The European counterattack, a response to U.S. measures on steel and aluminum, adds another front to a trade war that has engulfed allies and adversaries around the world.
articles.abstract: The European counterattack, a response to U.S. measures on steel and aluminum, adds another front to a trade war that has engulfed allies and adversaries around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: GOTEBORG, Sweden — The European Union fought back on Friday against the Trump administration’s tariffs, slapping penalties on an array of American products that target the president’s political base, like bourbon, motorcycles and orange juice.

articles.headline: Biggest Banks Pass Fed’s Stress Tests
articles.snippet: The first round of the Fed’s annual stress tests found banks are prepared to withstand a downturn, which could presage big shareholder payouts next week.
articles.abstract: The first round of the Fed’s annual stress tests found banks are prepared to withstand a downturn, which could presage big shareholder payouts next week.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s biggest banks are strong enough to continue lending if the economy plunges into a severe downturn, an assessment by the Federal Reserve on Thursday that could fuel Wall Street’s calls to further relax financial regulations.
articles.byline: By Matt Phillips and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: A Day Care and a Dog Rescue Benefit: On Facebook, They Were Political Ads
articles.snippet: Glitchy enforcement of a new Facebook political ad policy is creating headaches for small businesses, news publishers, and other advertisers.
articles.abstract: Glitchy enforcement of a new Facebook political ad policy is creating headaches for small businesses, news publishers, and other advertisers.
articles.lead_paragraph: What do a day care center, a vegetarian restaurant, a hair salon, an outdoor clothing maker and an investigative news publisher have in common?

articles.headline: ABC Plans a ‘Roseanne’ Spinoff, Without Roseanne Barr
articles.snippet: The show was canceled last month because of the star’s racist tweet. A version of the series will return in the fall. Working title: “The Conners.”
articles.abstract: The show was canceled last month because of the star’s racist tweet. A version of the series will return in the fall. Working title: “The Conners.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Roseanne Barr may be finished, but the Conners are not.

articles.headline: Migrant Parents Wait and Hope for Their Children: ‘I Feel Like I’m Going to Die’
articles.snippet: President Trump’s executive order aimed to halt future separation of migrant families, but parents of children still in detention say they still have no idea how to get them back.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s executive order aimed to halt future separation of migrant families, but parents of children still in detention say they still have no idea how to get them back.
articles.lead_paragraph: AURORA, Colo. — Micaela Samol Gonzalez, dressed in blue detention scrubs, made her way to the front of a windowless courtroom in Colorado on Thursday and faced the judge. After she gave her name and arranged a future court date for her immigration case, the judge asked whether she had any questions.

articles.headline: Behind Trump’s Plan to Overhaul the Government: Scaling Back the Safety Net
articles.snippet: A small army of conservatives have produced dozens of initiatives like the cabinet reshuffle proposal, with the goal of dismantling the social welfare system.
articles.abstract: A small army of conservatives have produced dozens of initiatives like the cabinet reshuffle proposal, with the goal of dismantling the social welfare system.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, spurred on by conservatives who want him to slash safety net programs, unveiled on Thursday a plan to overhaul the federal government that could have a profound effect on millions of poor and working-class Americans.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Erica L. Green

articles.headline: Inside a Heist of American Chip Designs, as China Bids for Tech Power
articles.snippet: Micron, an American chip maker, says its designs were swiped to help a new Chinese plant. Washington sees a larger pattern, fueling tensions with Beijing.
articles.abstract: Micron, an American chip maker, says its designs were swiped to help a new Chinese plant. Washington sees a larger pattern, fueling tensions with Beijing.
articles.lead_paragraph: JINJIANG, China — With a dragnet closing in, engineers at a Taiwanese chip maker holding American secrets did their best to conceal a daring case of corporate espionage.

articles.headline: What Trump Should Learn From the ‘Banana War’
articles.snippet: The White House is eyeing tariffs on luxury imports such as perfume, handbags and wine. It might be drawing the wrong lesson from past trade fights.
articles.abstract: The White House is eyeing tariffs on luxury imports such as perfume, handbags and wine. It might be drawing the wrong lesson from past trade fights.
articles.lead_paragraph: With China retaliating, America’s allies reeling and markets skidding, maybe it’s time to take off the gloves in America’s burgeoning trade war.

articles.headline: The ‘Ruligans’ in Russia, Courtesy of Iceland
articles.snippet: Given something to cheer for, Iceland’s soccer fan group grew from a few outliers in plastic Viking helmets into a singing, thunder-clapping force.
articles.abstract: Given something to cheer for, Iceland’s soccer fan group grew from a few outliers in plastic Viking helmets into a singing, thunder-clapping force.
articles.lead_paragraph: VOLGOGRAD, Russia — In the lean years of Icelandic soccer, roughly defined as the years before 2011, it was hard to get anyone excited about the national team. Icelanders tend to be phlegmatic. Their idea of an anti-government riot is getting together and throwing yogurt at the Parliament building.

articles.headline: What Stress? It's Good to Be a Bank
articles.snippet: The fortunes of the largest United States banks have changed remarkably over the past decade. So is it time to loosen regulation?
articles.abstract: The fortunes of the largest United States banks have changed remarkably over the past decade. So is it time to loosen regulation?
articles.lead_paragraph: What a time to be a bank.

articles.headline: Italy’s Economy Was Humming Nicely. Then Came Trump.
articles.snippet: Between the Trump administration’s steel tariffs, the reinstatement of sanctions on Iran, and political chaos, Italy is again struggling economically.
articles.abstract: Between the Trump administration’s steel tariffs, the reinstatement of sanctions on Iran, and political chaos, Italy is again struggling economically.
articles.lead_paragraph: GIOIA TAURO, Italy — From its headquarters in Calabria, the poorest, least-developed region in Italy, Gruppo Ventura looked out on the world and spotted a potentially lucrative growth opportunity — Iran.

articles.headline: Saudi Women Can Drive, but Here’s the Real Roadblock
articles.snippet: Despite some changes in Saudi society, a restrictive guardianship system means that women remain dependents of male relatives their whole lives.
articles.abstract: Despite some changes in Saudi society, a restrictive guardianship system means that women remain dependents of male relatives their whole lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: AL KHOBAR, Saudi Arabia — With her bubble-gum pink hair and stylishly ripped jeans, Doaa Bassem goes a long way to redefining what it means to be a Saudi woman these days.

articles.headline: Brazil Gets Its First Win, a Triumph of Grit More Than Style
articles.snippet: Phillippe Coutinho and Neymar both scored in stoppage time to keep Brazil’s World Cup run on level footing. With the loss, Costa Rica is eliminated.
articles.abstract: Phillippe Coutinho and Neymar both scored in stoppage time to keep Brazil’s World Cup run on level footing. With the loss, Costa Rica is eliminated.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russa — For so much of Friday afternoon, there was a battle going on in Russia between Brazil and Argentina, but it was nothing like the usual fight for supremacy these two imperious soccer nations usually wage.
articles.byline: By Matthew Futterman and Victor Mather

articles.headline: In Tense Meeting, Trump Officials Debate How to Process Migrant Families
articles.snippet: The reality of a vastly complicated bureaucratic system is colliding head-on with President Trump’s shoot-from-the-hip use of executive power.
articles.abstract: The reality of a vastly complicated bureaucratic system is colliding head-on with President Trump’s shoot-from-the-hip use of executive power.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tense arguments broke out at the White House over the past two days as top government officials clashed over how to carry out President Trump’s executive order on keeping together immigrant families at the Mexican border, according to four people familiar with the meetings.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Ron Nixon and Katie Benner

articles.headline: In Ruling on Cellphone Location Data, Supreme Court Makes Statement on Digital Privacy
articles.snippet: The 5-to-4 decision, in which the court said a warrant was generally needed to collect troves of the data, has implications for all kinds of personal information held by third parties.
articles.abstract: The 5-to-4 decision, in which the court said a warrant was generally needed to collect troves of the data, has implications for all kinds of personal information held by third parties.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a major statement on privacy in the digital age, the Supreme Court ruled on Friday that the government generally needs a warrant to collect troves of location data about the customers of cellphone companies.
